CARDINAL . The ORG was established by LAW DATE . Under LAW , the ORG is required , once a complaint is referred to it , to determine whether an investigation is required and , if so , in what form , having regard to the seriousness of the alleged misconduct and the public interest ( Schedule CARDINAL , paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . The possible forms of investigation are ( a ) an internal ( local ) investigation by the police force in question ; ( b ) an investigation under the supervision of the ORG ; ( c ) an investigation under the management of the ORG ; ( d ) an investigation by the ORG . In a “ supervised investigation ” , the investigating police force proposes an investigating officer and terms of reference which must then be approved by the ORG . The ORG conducts a regular review of the investigation , but responsibility for maintaining the record of decisions and for conducting a timely investigation rests with the force . A “ managed investigation ” involves the ORG setting the terms of reference in consultation with the police force . The investigating officer is nominated by that force but must be approved by the ORG . Paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of Schedule DATE Act provides that the person selected can be a member of the same police force as the investigated officers or of a different force . Once appointed , the investigator is under the direction and control of the ORG and responsibility for maintaining the record of decisions and ensuring a timely investigation is conducted rests with the ORG . While there is the possibility of an appeal to the ORG in connection with a local or a supervised investigation , there is no such right of appeal following an investigation carried out or managed by the ORG itself , although judicial review is available .

CARDINAL . As regards the appropriate mode of investigation in cases raising issues under LAW and/or CARDINAL of the LAW , paragraph CARDINAL of the LAW in force during the time of the events in question stated as follows :
“ NORP Convention on Human Rights

CARDINAL . Where the alleged conduct of a person serving with the police has resulted in death or serious injury Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW may be engaged . If they are engaged , the ORG , as a public authority under LAW DATE , has an obligation to determine a form of investigation that is an effective independent investigation that does not have any hierarchical or institutional connection with those implicated in the events . It would only not have to do that where there has been an inquest that satisfied LAW . An independent investigation into a death conducted by the ORG itself would satisfy the requirement of independence under LAW . An ORG managed investigation into a death involving the police would satisfy the requirement of independence under LAW provided that it was conducted by an external police force . Not all death or serious injuries that occur following contact with the police will engage LAW . For example where the death was obviously from natural causes or the police contact was sufficiently remote from the time of the death or serious injury . ”

“ CARDINAL . The Taser is a pistol - like device which shoots CARDINAL probes from an attached cartridge . Wires are attached to the probes . CARDINAL . The introduction of Tasers goes back to ORG in DATE ( ‘ A New Beginning : Policing in Northern Ireland’ ) which had called for substantial investment in research to find an acceptable , effective and less potentially lethal alternative to the plastic baton round . Tasers were developed in GPE . They were first used in the GPE in DATE . Originally , their use was confined to firearms officers . A somewhat wider use of them is allowed now by specially trained units ( at least in some police forces ) . It was firearms officers who used them on this occasion , but the Claimant relies on the potentially wider use of Tasers as CARDINAL reason why this incident merits particularly careful investigation .

CARDINAL . The use of Tasers is closely monitored . Every incident in which a ORG is deployed ( whether discharged or not ) is reported to the ORG ( ‘ ACPO’ ) and ORG . A panel of independent medical experts reviews periodically the use of Tasers . They comment that no deaths or serious injuries attributed to ORG use have occurred since the introduction of the device in DATE . They assess the risk of death or serious injury from the use of Tasers within ORG as very low . It is not CARDINAL as there have been CARDINAL reported incidents in the GPE of subjects who sustained fatal head injuries as a result of ORG - induced falls . ACPO guidance is that PERSON should only be used where officers are facing violence or threats of violence of such severity that they need to use force to protect the public , themselves or the subject .

CARDINAL . The ORG ’s approach to the use of PERSON has varied over time . In DATE when they were first introduced , the ORG ’s predecessor , ORG , required the police to refer to it any incident in which a Taser had been discharged . The ORG supervised the first few investigations into Taser use because of the considerable public interest , but since that time the vast majority of matters have been sent back to the police force concerned for local investigation . In DATE , the ORG changed the criteria for referral . They were brought into line with referrals where firearms were discharged i.e. referral to the ORG was required whenever their use : ( i ) resulted in death or serious injury ; ( ii ) caused danger to the public ; or ( iii ) revealed failings in command . Police forces could , of course , voluntarily refer other uses of ORG . In DATE , the ORG responded to the pilot project to allow specially trained units ( and not just firearms officers ) to use Tasers . In the forces which participated in the pilot , the ORG required all public complaints concerning the use of Tasers to be referred to it . In DATE the extension on use of Tasers to specially trained units was applied nationally . In consequence , from DATE , the ORG requires any complaints involving the use of Tasers to be referred to it . ”
PERSON found that , on the facts of the case , a procedural duty arose under LAW , for the following reasons :

“ CARDINAL . ... I have to say that I do not regard the experiences of the Claimant as anywhere near the borderline that is perhaps represented by minor bruising or scratches . “ CARDINAL . I was not provided with an estimate of how much an independent investigation by the ORG would cost in this case . DATE and DATE , this was a feature of CARDINAL conduct or complaint cases referred to the Commission . Having reviewed the relevant principles relating to the procedural obligation under LAW , PERSON dismissed the claim , as follows :

“ DATE . It is accepted that the Claimant suffered significant pain and injuries which , if not justified in the circumstances , would amount to the infliction of inhuman or degrading treatment contrary to LAW . He is entitled to have that claim effectively investigated . To be effective , the investigation must be independent . It is also accepted that the local investigation currently being carried out by ORG will not be independent . However , if the investigation were to lead to the prosecution of the officers concerned , the criminal trial would be ( or , at least , could be ) the effective investigation which LAW . Furthermore , if the Claimant ’s mother ( who made the complaint to the police about his treatment ) is dissatisfied with the information which is provided to her , with the findings of the local investigation or with its outcome , she can appeal to the ORG . That is a route which is regularly used by complainants and with some success . It increases the possibility that there will be a prosecution . It also allows for the chance that any deficiency in the local investigation can be remedied . All of this means that it can not be said at this stage that the ORG ’s direction that her complaint should be examined locally will inevitably breach the Claimant ’s right to an effective investigation . I would not have held that the possibility of civil proceedings by the Claimant was a means of providing the investigation required by LAW . The NORP authorities reject the possibility and comments to the contrary in the domestic authorities were not necessary for the decisions in those cases . However , whether I am right or wrong about the relevance of the possibility of civil proceedings is beside the point . The other reasons which I have given are sufficient for my conclusion that this application must be dismissed . ”
